docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., the nation's largest health insurer, posted a 65 percent decline in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday and said that it would shed 1.9 million more customers this year as it struggles to catch up with more profitable competitors. As it races to raise premiums ahead of costs, Aetna said it expected to shrink to about 17 million members, about 4 million fewer than in August 1999 after it bought Prudential Health, a huge money-losing unit of the Prudential Life Insurance Company of America. Only about 2 million former Prudential members would remain from the 5.3 million on the roster when Aetna completed the acquisition.
docs.abstract: Aetna Inc, nation's largest health insurer, posts 65 decline in fourth-quarter earnings and says it will shed 1.9 million more customers this year as it struggles to catch up with more profitable competitors; earnings plunged to $28.7 million compared with $81 million year ago; revenue for quarter declined $100 million (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Westchester chiropractor and four accomplices billed insurance companies for more than $10 million in fake or inflated claims at a network of medical centers in Westchester and Rockland Counties, federal prosecutors said today. After the five men were arraigned this morning in Federal District Court here, prosecutors said the chiropractor, Andrew Orlander of Chappaqua, ran the centers through a front company, paying a medical doctor several hundred thousand dollars a year to act as their owner, to circumvent a state law that bars chiropractors from owning medical practices. Mr. Orlander, 42, was also charged with laundering the proceeds and conspiring to help personal injury lawyers inflate their patients' claims to win higher awards in civil cases against insurers.

headline.main: Fraud Charged at Six Clinics In Westchester and Rockland

docs.lead_paragraph: Benefits for Palladin Top chefs and restaurateurs are coming to the aid of Jean-Louis Palladin, 54, who is being treated for lung cancer. His restaurant in the theater district, Palladin, closed a few weeks ago. Napa, his restaurant in Las Vegas, remains open.

docs.lead_paragraph: Like many pediatricians, Dr. Amit Shrivastava is finding that more parents of his young patients are asking him these days about a nasty virus known by its initials, R.S.V. Prompted by a new wave of advertisements by a biotechnology drug company called MedImmune, worried parents are asking Dr. Shrivastava, who works in Ithaca, N.Y., if their babies could contract R.S.V., or respiratory syncytial virus. If so, should they receive a treatment called Synagis?

headline.main: Doctors Caught in the Middle; Ad Campaign Has Parents Asking for a Costly Drug

docs.abstract: Pediatricians are debating whether to prescribe MedImmune Inc's drug Synagis, which fights respiratory syncytial virus in babies at cost of about $5,000 for five monthly injections; MedImmune's advertising campaign for drug has parents asking for costly drug; Synagis does not prevent respiratory syncytial virus, which infects nearly every child, but makes it symptoms less severe; among children less than one year old, virus is most common cause of pneumonia and bronchiolitis; debate among pediatricians about Synagis is also providing window into large concerns over whether America's health care systemm is in position to draw line between proper and improper use of all expensive new drugs being developed; sales of Synagis totaled $427 million in 2000, but analysts say sales could reach more than $800 million per year as more pediatricians prescribe it; graph; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When visitors come to her home for the first time, little Marie Estevez is reluctant to come out of her room. When she finally emerges, she hides behind her mother's sweater and peeks around her mother's side with her good eye. Marie rarely leaves the apartment because she does not want people, especially other children, to see her face.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Longing to Look Just Like Her Twin

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush unveiled a plan today to provide billions of dollars to the states to help nearly one-fourth of the 39 million Medicare beneficiaries buy prescription drugs, but the White House hinted by its actions and its words that Mr. Bush would not insist on the details of his proposal. Members of Congress from both parties expressed a distinct lack of enthusiasm for the president's proposal, which Mr. Bush called ''an immediate helping hand'' for low-income elderly people.

headline.main: BUSH PROPOSES AID ON MEDICARE DRUGS

docs.abstract: Pres Bush unveils plan to provide billions of dollars to states to help nearly one-fourth of 39 million Medicare beneficiaries buy prescription drugs, even though White House hints Bush will not insist on details of proposal; says proposal could provide interim access to drug coverage for 9.5 million of most vulnerable Medicare beneficiaries, until Congress approves fundamental changes in program; under plan, subsidized drug coverage would be offered as stop gap measure to people with annual incomes up to 75 percent above poverty level; coverage would be comparable to that provided federal and state employees; White House says Bush is fleshing out proposal made during presidential campaign, under immense pressure from Democratic nominee Al Gore; major aspects of plan highlighted; members of Congress from both parties express distinct lack of enthusiasm (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR much of the last century, employment in America rested on an exchange that contemplated far more than a day's wages for a day's work: it was all about a bundle of unspoken long-term commitments. Employees gave companies their loyalty -- however grudgingly -- in return for training, promotions, steady raises, job security and identity. Smirk all you like about the Organization Man; his trade-off made possible the 30-year mortgages and college educations that the great American dream was historically made of. In its day, the pact could reinforce itself for a lifetime, for the higher one climbed in a company, the greater the rewards and the stronger the incentive to stick around and try for more.

headline.main: Luring the Best in an Unsettled Time

docs.abstract: Companies are searching urgently for new ways to foster old-fashioned loyalty and commitment among employees, most of whom have little institutional loyalty left after years of downsizings, outsourcings and restructurings; several influential corporations are experimenting with concept called 'employer of choice,' in which they seek to identify traits of model employees, figure out what these people want in job and see to it that these people think they will find it more reliably at their company than anywhere else; trick is to win employees' sense of old-fashioned commitment without locking company into old-fashioned employment arrangement; compensation experts say last generation's weapons for fighting war for talent--excellent health insurance and pension plans, and seniority-based compensation schemes--are nonstarters today, because companies must maintain flexibility; photos; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Curt Blefary, the Baltimore Oriole outfielder who was the American League's rookie of the year in 1965, two years after the Yankees allowed him to be claimed from their farm system, died Sunday at his home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 57. The cause was pancreatitis, his family said.

headline.main: Curt Blefary, 57, Outfielder And A.L. Rookie of the Year

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 India Reels From Quake; Homelessness Multiplies In Bhuj, near the epicenter of a devastating earthquake that struck the western state of Gujarat on Friday, thousands are dead and hundreds of thousands are homeless. The violence of the quake, the worst in India in 50 years, brought whole neighborhoods crashing down. A12 Underequipped and understaffed doctors and soldiers tried desperately to rescue as many quake victims as possible. Most of the people still buried in the rubble are presumed dead. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: At noon Monday, Democrats in the Assembly and their allies in women's organizations, are scheduled to announce the passage of a bill called the Women's Health and Wellness Act. Among other things, it would require insurance companies to cover annual breast cancer exams for women over 40 and compel prescription drug coverage to include contraceptives. The Assembly vote will come less than a week after the Republican-led Senate, which has killed similar Democratic bills three years in a row, passed its own version of the bill. There are major differences between the two -- most notably, a provision in the Republican bill that allows religious institutions opposed to birth control to restrict contraceptive coverage for their employees -- and any negotiations toward a compromise measure will no doubt involve the usual rancor in the divided Legislature.

headline.main: Legislature Still Divided Over Women's Health Bill

docs.abstract: New York State Legislature remains divided over women's health bill; major difference between bills in Democratic-led Assembly and Republican-led Senate is provision in Republican bill that allows religious institutions opposed to birth control to restrict contraceptive coverage for their employees (M)
